conclusion: Objects A and B are two cloth pieces held above the coffee-table.
Objects C, D, E, F are four rigid blocks (two on the left, two on the right).
The cloth pieces are released so they can fall under gravity.
Gravity pulls each cloth straight down.
First contact will happen with the upper edges of the blocks directly beneath each cloth.
Once a cloth’s first few nodes touch the top corners of the blocks, the cloth drapes and continues sliding down along the sides until it rests on the tabletop.
Because the blocks are taller than the tabletop, they act as supports: the cloth cannot pass through them, so it bends around them.
The cloth forms a tent-like shape whose creases trace the vertical edges of the blocks.
Each cloth eventually touches the table everywhere except where the blocks are in the way; there it remains suspended on the block’s top face or wraps partly down its sides.
Left side (cloth A) lies over blocks C (white) and D (brown). Creases run from C’s and D’s top edges down to the table.
Right side (cloth B) lies over blocks E (yellow) and F (green) in the same fashion.
Overall, both cloths come to rest, draped neatly, with four visible humps where the blocks push the fabric upward.
When A and B are let go they fall, hit the tops of C–F, drape around them, and finally settle on the table so that each block produces a raised bump in its respective cloth.
